answers.answer: I would definitely get this checked out.  A bruise nor a scrape should last this long.  Are you sure you're not hitting your leg while sitting, and keeping it bruised or sore?  Is it  swollen at all?  A blood clot would cause a red, inflamed area, so I would rule this out.  My husband has diabetes and PAD, lack of blood flow to his legs, and has never experienced a symtom like this.  So, I also wouldn't think it has anything to do with blood flow.  I've been around a long time and one thing I've learned is that sometimes to get something looked into, you must exaggerate a little.  Tell your doctor that it has becomes very painful, and you would feel better if he would perform any necessary tests to determine what it is.  I used to keep a bruise on my thigh which was also sore.  I was becoming worried, and noticed one day at work that everytime I tried to cross my legs under my desk, I would bang my thigh on the desk!  So, this was an easy one to figure out.  I can't help but think you may also be doing something unknowingly.  But if you feel you're not, I would not rest on this and get it checked out.

you are on a higher level of aspirin each day than me and I've had heart attacks. I bleedfor a lot longer than normal and bruise much easier. Just a sharp tap can cause bruisingwith me and if I cut myself shaving I look like I've been in a road accident for hours.If you have no shortness of breath, no throat discomfort, no jaw ache, no chest painsand given that you don't smoke, I would say you probably fine. It is always worth havingregular checkups if heart problems have run in your family. I have picked a route whichtakes me 30 minutes to walk and I do this every day. I know every feeling in my body asI walk the route and will know if there is anything going wrong. With early signs of heartproblems you usually notice them during exertion and then they disappear when you rest. People who don't exercise will not have this luxury because they are always at restand so the signs appear and there is no way they can allow the heart to relax any further.You sound like you are quite worried about developing heart disease, but this worry isn'tgoing to do you any good in the long run.

question: I'm a 49 yr. old white male 6'3" 220 lbs.  My father died at age 74 of extreme congestive heart failure (90+% blockage).  On my last ECG (4/09) my family doctor indicated that there "might" be a small Q-wave, but he dismissed it as a minor issue on an otherwise good ECG.  I had a healthy treadmill stress test result about 5 years ago.  I've recently developed a moderate bruise on the back of my right shin that is not an injury from being hit, it just started to show up and is sore, along with a mild ache in the same calf.  I also have a small scrape in the same area that has been there for over a year.  I'm generally healthy and active, no drugs, alcohol, or nicotine, and no diabetes, hypertension or other issues.  I take vitamins B,E,C, and calcium along with 10mg of Lipitor and a 81 mg aspirin daily.  As a result choloesterol is normal (160ish total).I'm starting to wonder if this is indicating developing heart problems such as early failure, blockages starting, or something else, as all issues seem to be on my lower right extremities.  If so, what treatment, how, who and when?  My family doctor often dismisses things unless there are blatant symptoms or discomfort so hasn't recommended anything.
title: Cause for alarm?
